The Fibonacci numbers Fn have the initial values 
F0 = 0, F1 = 1, and the recursion Fn = Fn-1 + Fn-2 if n > 2. 

The Fibonacci sequence is a set of integers that starts with 0 and 1, where each subsequent number is the sum of the two preceding numbers.

The Tribonacci numbers Tn have the initial values T0 = 0, T1 = 0, T2 = 1, and the recursion Tn = Tn-1 + Tn-2 + Tn-3 if n > 3.\n\nThe Tribonacci numbers form a sequence where each number is the sum of the three preceding numbers.

The Lucas numbers Ln have the initial values L0 = 2, L1 = 1, and the recursion Ln = Ln-1 + Ln-2 if n > 2.\n\nLucas numbers are a set of numbers with the same properties as Fibonacci, but they start with 2 and 1 instead of 0 and 1.

In mathematics, the Euclidean algorithm is an efficient method for computing the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two integers.\n\nThe GCD is the largest number that divides the two integers without a remainder. While, the Least Common Multiple (LCM) is used to find the smallest positive integer that is divisible by two or more given integers.

The Collatz sequence is a sequence of numbers relevant to the Collatz conjecture, which theorizes that any number using this algorithm will eventually be reduced to 1.\n\nThe initial value can be any POSITIVE ODD INTEGER. If the previous term is odd, use 3n + 1 to obtain the next term. If the previous term is even, it is divided by 2.
